sense.name: an excursion on foot
sense.examples: John takes the dog for a walk every evening after dinner. Employees are encouraged to take walks at noontime for their health.

sense.name: a style or quality of walking
sense.examples: Bob has a confident walk. The news put a bounce back into her walk. Runway models cultivate a distinctive walk with hips thrust forward.

sense.name: the rate or pace of a slow gait
sense.examples: The rider took his horse around the ring at a walk, then at a trot. The child tried to keep up with his father's fast walk through the airport. Mary grew tired of the crowd's slow walk through the exhibition hall.

sense.name: a paved footpath
sense.examples: I had to shovel the walk after it snowed. A brick walk leads to the restaurant's outdoor dining deck.

sense.name: a route or a distance done on foot
sense.examples: The Freedom Trail is an historical walk you can take through Boston. The library is only a five-minute walk from here. The landscape architect has designed a number of beautiful walks through the botanical garden.

sense.name: a social fundraising event done on foot
sense.examples: She does a lot of walks for charity each year. They are organizing a walk for hunger next month. The local walk for breast cancer raised several thousand dollars.

sense.name: a social role or position
sense.commentary: WALK[+role][+social][+position] Note: usually in the phrase 'walks of life'
sense.examples: This course attracts people from many different walks of life. Bob came from a different walk of life than Mary.

sense.name: advancement to first base on 4 balls in baseball
sense.examples: They retired the pitcher after he pitched three walks in a row. With the bases loaded, they cannot afford a walk now.
